ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: It's cool to get to go to the UN and get a sense of how work is done there.
What I liked most about the course was the internship. I learned more during the internship than in the class.
Internship experience at the UN and the class focused on UN negotiation procedures complemented each other well.

The partnership between this course and the internship is a unique and extraordinary opportunity. The course provides the background and introduction to United Nations protocol and process, and the internship provides an incredible hands-on application of course material.
the discussion and the internship
The internship at the United Nations
Getting an introduction to international frameworks and negotiations, and applying those in an internship.
The opportunity of working at the UN.
Internship experience at the UN and the class focused on UN negotiation procedures complemented each other well.
The internship, as backed by the course. It was incredible!

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: sturcture
It would have been helpful to have background reading supplemental to class discussions each week.

Wrapping up in a timely manner; with the very busy schedules that typify FES student life, it is frustrating to have to stay 20 minutes or more after each class, or be forced to walk out while the professor is still talking.
More organization during the seminar. Some times we received the reading one night before the class. I would like to know with more time to prepare for the class.
the course is often run by UN schedule. although that is understandable given the set up of the course, I think having a more structured outline of the course is useful.

If started sooner (i.e., at the very beginning of the semester), students could get even more out of the internship placements. Getting these logistics sorted out could improve the classroom experience too, as it's much easier to understand UN protocol once you're sat in on a meeting.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Kartikeya was very accessible and helpful, Professor Lee as well even though he's not often on campus.
Both were very accessible
Both instructor and TA was readily available by email.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I want to study international environmental policy, so this was the perfect class and experience for me.
Good for anyone interested in international diplomacy and/or climate change negotiations

This course is very helpful, because it exposed me to an international environment I wouldn't get in any other form. I learned about the functioning of the UN and its negotiations from the inside and not from books or other's experiences.

It is a great course for those who are interested in UN as a possible future career path down the road. This course allows to understand UN as a system, and provides an opportunity to take part in negotiation settings real time.
This course has given a new direction to my work and research, and has opened my eyes about professional opportunities I would enjoy.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: UN intership is a interesting opportunity.
I took this course because of the internship aspect of the course to take the opportunity to intern at the United Nations.
Have always been interested in international policy, and this seemed like the kind of opportunity (to intern at the UN) that you come to Yale to be able to do.
In order to gain UN experience in the position of delegates.
To get a hands on introduction to the UN and sustainable development (within international law)

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: mostly
YES!

It started out very slowly for me, the pace of the class and the length of time to actually get an internship, but over time I grew to very much appreciate the opportunity, especially going to NYC weekly.
yes.
The course gave a preliminary introduction to the UN, and the internship gave an incredible learning experience above and beyond expectations.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: part of my expectation.
YES!
Yes
yes, I was provided with an opportunity to take part in meetings and brief on behalf of the mission.
More

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The group work was arranged during the weekend, so students did not have enough time.
Learning from my peers about topics that I wasn't familiar with.
We all contributed to a comment letter that was submitted to the UNFCCC; it was a good thing to force us to collaborate and come to agreement on the issues we were learning about in the class.
Advantages of the group work:was able to create a fine/useful document with a collaborative effort in a short period of timeDisadvantage:hard to coordinate time and place for everyone

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: You must be independently motivated and ambitious in order to get the most out of your internship experience.
Be patient, it is taught in a more meandering, less structured style than what you're used to. It may be challenging to stay engaged, but you can get a good deal out of it if you care to.
Consider that some times the time devoting to the internship might be too much, compared to other courses work load.
participate in class discussions actively.

Try to get your internship started immediately, and put a lot into it. The more you put into it, the more you'll get out. Students who started with their Missions full time after finals let out (in the spring) got much more out of their overall experience.
